"In 1995 the World Health Organization (WHO) and the United Nations Interregional Crime and Justice Research Institute (UNICRI) announced in a press release the publication of the results of the largest global study on cocaine use ever undertaken. An American representative in the World Health Assembly banned the publication of the study, because it seemed to make a case for the positive uses of cocaine. An excerpt of the report strongly conflicted with accepted paradigms, for example, "that occasional cocaine use does not typically lead to severe or even minor physical or social problems." In the sixth meeting of the B committee, the US representative threatened that "If World Health Organization activities relating to drugs failed to reinforce proven drug control approaches, funds for the relevant programs should be curtailed". This led to the decision to discontinue publication. A part of the study was recuperated and published in 2010, including profiles of cocaine use in 20 countries, but are unavailable as of 2015."

There isn't even a war to win, here. There's an aspect of humans being human that often leads to problems in peoples lives, but which is likely to always exist to some extent.

I suppose if we "got tougher" I suppose we could just force people to become what we want to force them to be, though. Maybe torture (or more torture) would do the trick? But I doubt if it's worthwhile. That vector seems to extend in a quite scary direction, actually. If I was on a train heading off on a journey that might have no end in that direction, I think I might jump out the window and see if I get lucky and survive this, rather.

I think it's pretty obvious that the very best way to cope with the problem aspects of peoples use of mind-altering substances (like alcohol, and in subtle ways, nicotine, and others of course) would be to have a state monopoly over these. That way you have some actual control over the phenomenon, after all. And the costs of the problem could be borne by the people who take the risk. Sounds fair to me? Sell drugs at a profit, and put the profit into something useful.

First line of defence: Try to achieve perfect Informed Consent on the part of users. Have a "layered" "drug-driver's-licence" system, where before you gamble your life on the small beer, you "do the Knowledge" - attend and pass a course that imparts the current best knowledge of the nature of the substance first. Then abuse small beer for a few months to qualify to do the full-beer course. And then the Special Brew course. And then maybe the dope course - depending on what the Relative Harm Scale of the day says is the next most dangerous. Onward and upward, if you insist, too. Right to the heroin course or the crystal meth course. Offer a bit of resistance. Just take great pains to be utterly reasonable about this, though. That might be enough to save quite a lot of people, just by prevention; and part of the Knowledge for heavier stuff would be things like, "How to tell that it's getting out of hand", and, "How to get help."

And then finally, be willing to give something to "completely worthless people" (put that way just to bring even those who feel that way about addicts on board). As a last resort, be ready to feed and house a certain proportion of people who refuse to work, and just want to dive deep into the drug world. You could put some reasonable restrictions on some people, though. No children, for instance. If you do heroin, you get an IUD or vasectomy (could put a straw or so of semen in a sperm bank just in case of recovery, but if you make yourself incompetent as a parent, you shouldn't even become the "parent" that only contributes some sperm). And maybe if you do the deep dive, you have to volunteer to be part of the world's "brain astronaut" workforce? You blow your mind; allow us to read it if we can; between us, humanity gains some new knowledge, and the voluntary guinea pig suffers no harm not voluntarily assumed.

That last bit is important. If we're tight fisted toward the people who will still unravel due to drugs, we push them into desperation. And in desperation we already know that the world of drugs does things like keep the world supplied with child prostitutes "sold" by their desperate mothers. With our complicity. If she's scum, so are we.

It's a bit of a complicated replacement for the War on Drugs, but at least it meets those who have legitimate reasons for those bad policies half way. And if you just go all "Reagan-Hippy Free Enterprise Cures all Disease" when dropping the war, you legitimize some businesses whose proprietors should probably be banished to Antarctica without blankets. There's no need to make "respectable" (with "respect" being something else, surely?) citizens out of the dealers. Let them suffer. It's OK. It doesn't matter if they suffer. Not the least bit. It's just the addicts that need some compassion here. Focusing on how the newly gentrified scum are going to have nice little businesses after the "peace" completely misses the whole point of ending the "war".

No, the war on drugs isn't a failure. It's doing what it set out to do. I don't mean reducing drug abuse, addictions, or related socioeconomic and health concerns, because that's what its official goal is. The unofficial and actual goal is to systematically target minorities and working-class citizens and use them as an excuse for racism and legal slavery during their prison sentence. The 80s saw the rise of the private prison system that exists solely to profit off of prison slave labor. Outside of that, making drugs illegal doesn't eliminate the demand, so there are going to be illegal organizations, such as the mafia, cartels, and street gangs who provide the supply and protect their enterprises all outside the boundaries of the law, making related crimes of murder, extortion, robberies, racketeering, and others a common practice for a billion-dollar industry, which, in turn, allows ignorant people to justify racist practices, social stigmas against the working class, and associate entire countries with their drug markets. Rich people do drugs, too, but when they do, it's treated as a scandal on the same level as cheating on a spouse if they're caught, and they have access to rehabilitation because they have money. They can also fake going to rehab or continue to do the drugs in secret because they have the money and the ability to feed their drug habit while experiencing little if any, jail or rehab time. So long as racist, corrupt governments (like the United States) and the corporations that benefit from their laws exist, the war on drugs will never end because it won't stop the racist practices that make them rich.

If you want to address a health problem, you need a healthcare solution. The perfect example is the pandemic we're living in now. You don't go around arresting people who have COVID-19 or killing them to stop the disease, you make it so you treat the sick and prevent further cases through vaccinations and lockdowns. The drug abuse solution is simple: legalize all substances, make them simple to get, and create safe areas for people to get high without the risk of OD'ing while providing counseling options, with many of them being free. This shifts the demand to a legal market where illegal enterprises hold no power and save more lives by treating it as a health, rather than a criminal problem. If you think that sounds ludicrous, that's exactly what Portugal did to address their drug problem, and drug-related deaths declined by over 50% in one year in that nation.

"But who's going to pay for that? Isn't that communism? What about this and that and blah blah blah."

I'm sure most Americans and citizens of other nations would prefer to see their loved ones treated at a government-funded hospital rather than suffer at a private or government-funded prison. This practice is as communist as the current COVID-19 vaccine rollouts happening worldwide. We don't hate people who have addictions, as opposed to violent criminals, we pity them. We wish they could get help. But the sad truth is that most of them don't know how to get help without potentially breaking whatever savings they have or aren't aware of the options available to them. Why? Because the war on drugs is so deeply embedded in our societies now that the stigma is simple: Do drugs and you're a criminal. That's what the war on drugs wants, and that's why it's a resounding success.

Of course it's sponsored by the Open Society Foundation aka George Soros and the usual suspects. Let's get one point straight. Drugs make humans behave in terrible, destructive ways. This fact does not depend on rules imposed by society on itself.

In the United States, most drug abusers are arrested after royally screwing up, i.e. driving intoxicated, wrecking their car and endangering or killing others. Arresting people who are endangering others is common sense. You lose the privilege of driving AND making your own choices.

Why do people in the US engage in so much drug-related crime including theft, prostitution, etc.? It is to fund their addiction. When they run out of money, they turn to crime in order to get that money. Then they get in trouble with the law, and are subsequently arrested for the harm and destruction they cause other human beings. This is not unjust.

True, sometimes people are arrested on nonviolent possession charges. Perhaps there could be some reform here. But if you have ever worked in public service before, you know that drugs are almost always involved with harmful, illicit behavior. This behavior is unnecessary if you are a functional addict. Meaning that if addicts could be functional members of society, then they would not need to engage in worse crimes than possession, and subsequently be removed from the public sphere.

There are rehab centers in every major city across the US. Some people voluntarily go, many do not. The one thing about US rehab is in general we don't keep your addiction going, we help you quit cold turkey. Unfortunately this is extremely difficult to do, but it is necessary for long term health and happiness.

The real argument for or against the efficacy of the Swiss model is whether or not the model reduces drug dependence. This is a key metric - does reducing penalties actually reduce demand?

The Swiss model threatens to increase addiction due to the lack of penalty. Kurzegstat makes a good point about how certain societal ills can be reduced if someone intervenes in the process. But we need to know, does this actually help solve the drug addiction problem?

The ultimate goal of society should be to live sober and drug-free, not to help people continue making terrible choices. Believe me, it is possible to live this way, and quite common.

The Swiss model is also a war on drugs, it's just a different philosophy.

Your data concerning the information with Black kids get more often arrested for drug offenses but white kids are more likely to carry/distribute is tainted by two things. The link you place in your description is an article by an economic analysist who ignored certain aspects of the survey he mentions and bases the article off of. Omitting circumstances that occur and clear data that can affect the results and are not discussed in any way, leading me to believe he omitted the information on purpose to further a specific agenda he had. From the Analysis he mentions, said data you refer to (but didn't check yourself?) "NSDUH is representative of persons aged 12 and over in the civilian noninstitutionalized population of the United States, and in each state and the District of Columbia (D.C.). The survey covers residents of households (including those living in houses, townhouses, apartments, and condominiums), persons in noninstitutional group quarters (including those in shelters, boarding houses, college dormitories, migratory work camps, and halfway houses), and civilians living on military bases. Persons excluded from the survey include people experiencing homelessness who do not use shelters, active military personnel, and residents of institutional group quarters such as jails, nursing homes, mental institutions, and long-term care hospitals." One issue with this is omission of certain persons in specific housing quarters, which obviously affects results in one way or another and needs to be discussed. The other is the basis for the survey in the first place, in which anyone over the age of 12 is asked in person something along the lines of "Have you done X drug in the past months/year?". It is not discussed by the survey itself, nor the analysist of said article you use that surveys about illegal drugs have an error rate, and also people that lie....because some drugs are illegal....

As someone with untreatable depression, I agree with this completely. The only way to stop the pain was opiates. Had I had access to predictable doses at reasonable cost, I wouldn't have been in absolute misery for most of my life, and I wouldn't have been committing crime.

I didn't want to get wasted, I just needed a treatment that was otherwise impossible to obtain. Life would have been so much better without the rollercoaster of withdrawal, or the suffering of not having any money, associating with dangerous people, and the risk of disease and imprisonment.

Emotional pain is actual pain, and failing to treat severe pain is absolute cruelty, but everyone's hands were tied by a barbaric legal system. If I didn't want to spend my whole life tortured by indescribably horrible depression, I needed to break the law. There was no other way.

FYI, making drugs legal won’t solve all your problems. For example, marijuana in California being legalized created a new set of problems. Marijuana is legal, but regulated. This means only people with the proper licensing and methods can grow it legally. Legalization popped up 1000s of unpermitted growers. What’s wrong with unpermitted growers? Well they undercut the people who are doing it legally, and cut their profit margins so that the small businesses growers don’t make it and go bankrupt. The unpermitted growers also go out into national forests and set up illegal grows where they divert natural streams which kill native species of fish, they use illegal pesticides which are highly toxic to humans and wildlife, and the field workers living remotely in secrete have to live off the land and they kill every animal in a 10 mile radius for food. And illegal grow site is disgusting. Pesticides, trash, and dead animals everywhere. Oh a d those illegal growers carry guns. Even more fun for law enforcement. So just remember, legalizing doesn’t solve all your problems, there are new ones to tackle. I support the legalization of some drugs but only if the proper management of them is in place, which means you still need all those law enforcement agencies out there enforcing laws. Just a different set of them.

I think part of the problem with Switzerland’s approach (which is a fantastic approach we can learn from) is the diversity issue. Understanding the needs of a largely homogenous population is relatively simple; culture is ubiquitous, and social workers have an easier time understanding their patients.

But the United States is the most diverse country in the world. Social workers will find infinitely more difficulty in trying to help patients get through both their addiction(s) and personal issues that led to that point.

This being said, I still believe this approach is viable and that we should pursue it. Since our population is diverse, our social workers and revolving communities must be diverse as well. Unfortunately, our country’s inability to enact change quickly is preventing this from being done in earnest. Take Seattle for example. They’ve tried to solve drug use and incarceration by simply not enforcing laws; police make arrests for law abusers who need help, but they neither go to prison nor receive treatment. The effort is only half way, otherwise you are left with cities as dirty and disgusting as Seattle has become.

We need to do more. Again, this is where our weak government falls short. Even though intentions are good, we have yet to fully implement such a system. We have work to do, people!

I love it, Switzerland dealing with the cause and not the effect. But I would say a bigger problem that America is facing with its drugs is culture.  Yes, you can easily set up rehab clinics everywhere, and yes, you can create wholesome jobs for people to find beneficial purpose in life, BUT... controlling the environment is going to be difficult. Closing businesses that have a harmful effect on human mentality and physical health without having the data to back it up will be difficult, and even if you do have the data, the argument that because the substance does not kill someone instantly and effects are reversible means that it could be an issue held up in the courts for decades (e.g like trying to close a bakery store, not a nutritious product but the harmful effects are not instant). Let's see, on the DEMAND side, why do people do drugs?

It has to do with the purpose of the lower worlds, or what most of you know of as Earth (physical existence). This place is designed to teach spiritually immature people (read: just about everyone you know) cause and effect.

Most people are stuck in a loop of pursuing pleasure and avoiding pain. Rather than do the work of spiritual progress (which is harder), they self-medicate with drugs (which is easier). Human beings have a tendency to choose the path of least resistance in the murky pathways of their own minds, and so the result is a big, worldwide drug problem.

The solution is to evolve spiritually. Hardly anyone you know even knows what spirituality really is, much less has the ability to do anything about it. So, for the foreseeable future, drugs will remain a problem. But, spiritually evolved people know that it isn't a "real" problem, just like good students in class know that their job is to understand the purpose of the homework, not try to change the nature of the "problems" presented by their teachers.

Inevitably, there will be a few people reading this who think they are more clever than the system designed to help them evolve spiritually, and will cite that in school they would do various rebellious things because they knew better than their teachers what would they should be learning. These people sometimes go on to create Microsoft or Apple, but much more frequently live in the basement of their parents' house voting for Trump and wondering why they don't feel particularly good most days. Most people who think they are really clever, aren't, and the really successful people in life tend to constantly question themselves and wonder if maybe they could do things in a better way.

In America, we have methadone clinics. This is very similar to the Swiss approach to heroine use. Any opiate ends up being substituted with methadone. There are treatments that can get an opiate user to a drug free lifestyle. It's a small step in the right direction. And, it will take time for this war on drugs to resolve itself and dissolve into a more regulated system. With that, other problems will arise. But, it's a step in the right direction. We are slowly making more drugs legal in various states. We are developing treatments for drugs that were previously thought of as not useful for therapy. We are scheduling drugs to describe them to have more therapeutic potential and less harm potential. Thus, crime charges for drugs are becoming less intense. It's progress toward a better system. We cannot stop people from enjoying drugs by punishing them. We can only end this war through knowledge and effective use and regulation of drugs.

I'd like to add some details as to why treating heroin addicts with heroin works well.
Heroin slows down your heart rate and breathing. This is the reason why an overdose can be lethal. That said, the long term physical effects of heroin are surprisingly low and mainly related to that resulting lack of oxigen. The real problem of the substance itself is the high potential for addictions. That combined with street heroin usually containing less than 10% heroin in favor of other substances that are a lot more toxic than the heroin itself. Also the injection as method of application is even more dangerous than other methods.
Furthermore the active dose is not that much lower compared to the lethal dose. This means that, especially after developing some tolerance, just small errors in the dosage can have lethal consequences. And not knowing how much heroin actually is in your stuff makes these errors a lot more common.
Therefore the access to clean heroin can not only allow measures for improving the patients general or social life to take effect but also heavily improves their physical health.

I'm open for discussions so please tell me how you see things your way.

The way I see it now.
When I was growing up, meth and heroin were a huge problem.
I found thousands of needles in a park near my house and seeing addicts all around you was a pretty normal thing.
I've always been told not to do the drugs, but they've never told me why people were doing rhem in a first place.
Sadly several of my friends I used to know sice the first day of school ended up doing hard drugs and when you get the look from a first hand what led to them using the drugs it always was a low income bacground or having someone related doing them hearing all the "good" stuff it does to them even tho' it's literally killing them.
I grew up in a family where we wasn't the rich and sometimes not even the middle class.
I had to wear my brother's clothes and sometimes had the same soup for 6 days a week as a main meal so when I was seeing the other kuds flexin' with their kinder surprises next to their bagguettes I felt a bit "outcasted" with a simple bread with butter and one piece of cheese.
I've always wanted to get out of that position where people were eyeing me down because I had a worn shirt and a sweatpants with holes in my pockets...
When I was 16 my friend invited me for a "chill session" where he would smoke weed and pkay some games.
I agreed and wen't over
He then whipped out a joint and taught me how to smoke it.
There I was, experiencing my first stoner moments when he took a small bag out saying it's meth and was thinking of using it right there for the first time.
I can clearly remember I told him "Fuck that dude, why would you do it?" smiling my ass off whilst I was dead serious... the reason why I rememver it because he the said
"True, fuck that shit" threw it away and kept playing NHL.
After the weekend he came to school and told me he flushed it.
Week later he didn't come a single day.
The next week he showed up, clearly tired because his heas was falling down all the time like he didn't sleep at all for the past week he was completely unresponsive to any messages or calls.
The day after he didn't come and for the rest of the week he was gone again.
We then found out he deleted his facebook and his Steam account was renamed to some random name (he sold it).
He then sold his laptop we found out and even his fucking Playstation and xbox.
We knew something wasn't right and I had a feeling I knew what was going on.
He sometimes came to school, each time more and more hollow and he didn't talk at all.
Just kept staring into the space, the when class ended he got up and left.
Sure enough school started to investigate why he's skipping the school so much and later on our teacher told us he fell to drugs really hard.
The thing is me and him, we were both skinny af.
You could count our ribs wgen we had our shirts off, so imagine this, loosing even more weight.
It was really scary to look at gim knowing he was the guy I laughed my ass off every weekend playing games or just calling on Skype and just talk bullshit... now he was just walking like a fiend, not talking, his face was like a minefield of exploded mines ... just horrible .
But now we had a similiar thing as Switzerland, where we do not GIVE you drugs to use, but we do give out clean needles and help those people out if they want.
It took many years, but he then had his second near death experience when he was 22 and got helped.
He is a roma/gypsy which are a minority here in Czech Republic and sadly because of the past, they have a real hard time to get into normal lifestyle like others do.
His dad was a "oldschool gypsy" which I would describe as "Non-working, hard smoking and drinking, violent thug" ... it sounds super racist and stereotypical, but it is what it is.
He left them when my friend was 7 or so and sometimes showed up when he needed money.
His mother is an angel.
Such kind hearted person... I've never met another like this.
So he had the drive and foundation to be dufferent, but sadly he took the wrong turn that friday night and it fucked him up real bad.
He found help and right now it's his second year if being clean.
I sometimes talk to him and couple of days I saw him after like 5 years or even more.
Sure... it left a mark on him.
He isn't the loud, hyperactive and always talking person like he was, but seeing him smile and he telling me how he wore a bag over his head when he was going for clean needles so no one could recognize him was ... really hard to listen to.
Now...
Imagine if he didn't had the chance to get help, rather was fined and put to jail with fellony (at least that's what I think is you are charged for in the USA mainly if you are a minority)
It's just so fucking stupid and backwards...
I talked with him about this and he told me it's like playing Dark Souls, but with only 1 hp.
It is possible to finish the game (get clean) but it's really, REALLY hard where with every restart you are more leaned towards ragequitting (keep on returning to drugs)
I just can't imagine the state of thought when you are black, hyspanic or whatever in the US and having drug problems.
Another thing is healthcare in general... paying for even calling an ambulance, then for the time spent there and for getting fixed.
I'd rather rot alive then have some huge debt up my ass... another reason not to seek help (I've heard aboutfree organizations that helps addicts, but ffs it should be the state to take care of it's citizens, not other people from their good will)
Anyone wondering how medical stuff works here, it's that you pay insurance every month (~$50-$100 don't know exactly the number)
and everthing is for free.
You broke a bone? no problem.
You have some serious injury? same thing
But when you are emloyed anywhere... the employer the pays the insurance.
So if you work like a regular person should, there's nothing to care or worry about.
Well, anyone bored/interested to read this whole thing and having something to say, please do ... I don't know alot of things and I'd like to know where I was wrong so I do not spread out bullshit :) thank you and have great day my guys

After doing quite a bit of research on this subject for a proposed thesis. I've found the 'War on Drugs' to be one of the greatest failures in U.S. history. These failures include: Economic, Legislation, humanitarian, foreign relations, and adoption of corruption within government and policy .

From its very inception, it has been Machiavellian in nature written up by a President who was removed from office for his corruption and you got it.... His Machiavellian practices. Who would have thought he had 'The Prince' on his bedside table (ironic). Rarely did this administration mob which gave life to such a failure, consider the best interest of the 100's of millions of lives this would impact in a very negative manner.

The negative impact this has had, is by and large one of the greatest tragedies in the free world. Once again, defined by a person who felt it necessary to exercise their will above the constitution of the United States as a 'necessary evil'. There are absolutely zero studies suggesting that in any way, shape, or form that the 'war on drugs' has been successful. These negative impacts include: Popularizing drug culture, promoting systemic stigmas on behavioral health, exposing our police force, by over extending their responsibilities. In ways that are both unethical, and unconstitutional. We should not blame the police for failed policy and legislation. They didn't write it, they're enslaved to it.

It takes more lives of innocence than all of the world wars combined, but we still condone this, and go so far as to fund this with no study, scientific, or mass acceptance illustrating any success at all. Don't defund the police, end the greatest failure in U.S. history. End the 'war on drugs'. Sorry.... saying the 'war on drugs' feels idiotic in every sense of the word. It equivalent to saying 'the war on the mentally ill' or 'the war on the impoverished'. It's simply one of the dumbest things ever conjured up by a human. Which has created so much despair that it can never be reconciled, only forgot.... we will look back on it in the future as a brain fart, another shameful part of our rocky history. In the Netherlands the care for drug addicted people started in the sixties, by the alcohol treatment institutions. In the Netherlands the users were never criminalized, always viewed as patients. It was not official, there were to much problems with the rest of the world about our hash/marijuana policy.
It was mostly speed addiction, later also heroine. In the eighties the problem was more or less stable. No new cases. Nowadays the average drugaddict in the Netherlands is older than 50. I remember talking with a heroine addict in 1980, he looked very good, he was still using but in way more relaxed way. (he used to be a wrack)
The institutions now treat game addictions. They also test drugs on parties and monitors the safety of the drugs available. On internet you can find the procedure when you want to test your drugs. Of course treatment of more common addictions to alcohol, nicotine and gambling are also on their list.
And by the way, alcohol is for young people much more dangerous than marijuana. Even a little quantity of alcohol can do damage to the devolving brains. But don’t use a THC product 3 weeks before important exams, because your cognitive abilities decreases.

The reason there is a war on drugs in the first place is because of how irresponsible people can be with drug use. Instead, we should be regulating the use of drugs. Don't smoke weed everyday. Don't do DMT all the time. Don't eat mushrooms everyday. Also, don't do methamphetamine at all, ever. I love these videos, but this is a vast oversimplification of the problem, especially here in the U.S. The U.S. isn’t a homogenous society. Switzerland, by stark contrast, largely is. This bakes (no pun intended) a ton of problems into a one size fits all solution...until we get all Americans on the same program from an education, culture, and justice standpoint, across the board legalization would be a disaster.

I understand the point, but what they are describing has serious downsides as well. Similar experiments were tried in Denmark, but it was deemed a failure because it was found that no matter how much heroin was offered, the addicted would simply crave more and more. In the end, after they met their quota for the drugs they could receive legally, spent all their money on illegal drugs anyway.
I think the video might be ignoring one of the core principals of supply and demand when it comes to drug abuse. The higher the supply, the more the demand will naturally rise. Another thing that is completely ignores is that the economical wealth distribution is very different in USA and Switzerland. So it makes no sense to compare the two of them. Instead, compare the drug related issues with other countries like Denmark or Norway, which employ the "normal" drug enforcement methods, yet have even better statistics than Switzerland in anything drug related...

This is a useful video. It does a great job of explaining the problem. But I don't think it pushes the solution far enough.

I believe in Harm Reduction but notice that according to the video that Switzerland's method of Harm Reduction reduces OD death by 50%. So, yes, it's an improvement but the real solution is to end prohibition entirely.

As the video shows with the supply-side graph it is not possible to reduce demand of drugs by increasing the cost. But rather when the cost is decreased (as the penalities that one pays for consumption) demand goes down, which makes sense if one understands the history of prohibition and why people turn to drugs in the first place, again something this useful video doesn't really touch on.

I think the Bruce Alexender's Rat Park experiments as well as understanding of alienation social structure from an anthropological standpoint, says that mammals uses drugs when under stress. Therefore, reducing stress reduces the demand for drugs. This is one reason why Harm Reduction tends to work. However, thinking that Harm Reduciton alone is the solution and that prohibition can be in place and society can more or less go on as it is is misguided.

Prohibition needs to end, the social stresses that push the desire to consume drugs needs to be addressed, and sure HR outreach, most especially prescription heroin need to be in place. But to reverse all of these problems the best and easist and most cost-effective is to begin by ending prohibition.

We need to start protesting and marching for the end of prohibition and NOT just Harm Reduction as an adjunct to continued prohibition.

The very act of making drugs illegal is what's giving them value and motivating folks to manufacture and distribute it. Drug cartels don't want legalization, because illicit substances wouldn't have value if they were no longer illicit. It's the risk and difficulty in manufacturing and trafficking something illegal that makes it profitable..

So with that understanding, it's evident that the government is the entity that makes drugs more valuable, incentivizing a market for it, only to profit off of it by condemning anyone who's partaking in the market that they themselves created.. It's an industry where the government and drug cartels both profit, they depend on each other to uphold the entire thing. If the government really wanted to end the war on drugs, they would just legalize drugs..

Thus the US government has responded by attempting to sway public opinion towards legalization so that it can tax the substance and make money off it that way. This video is right. I'm 26 years old, i´ve been a heavy cannabis user for almost 6 years, I experimented with a lot of drugs (mostly hallucigens, among a few others). The opposite of addictive behaviour is connection; I felt alienated, far away, disconnected from my environment... Time passed, I met a beutiful and intelligent girl; so I decided to quit. I was experimenting problems with my memory as well. Don't get me wrong, I LOVED TO SMOKE! Cannabis (and other drugs) are awesome, and they can teach you a lot about appreciating life from other perspectives (I think that most should be legal and its usage be approached as a public health issue). The problem is when it becomes a habit based on addictive behaviour, maybe used as a cope mechanism; being high becomes your "new normal"(You don´t even realize it when you are in the middle of that "state").

With time, I realized that my heavy drug usage was based on the internal and almost unconscious deep feeling of feeling alienated, off, disconnected; All in all, the opposite of addiction is not sobriety, it is connection (We should meditate about this, and how we organize our societies).

I think the idea of harsh punishments is to scare people from using the drugs in the first place rather than to punish them. If you prevent them from using the drugs in the first place they don't become addicted and don't have to worry about losing a future job. And you can't just stop at marijuana. Unfortunately, if you really want to beat the cartels you have to legalize everything. If it is legal, then criminal elements have to go legit or fold. If it is legal, then it can be regulated, treatment made available. Do opioids ruin people's lives? They do. Alcohol does too. Tobacco does. But we both know making them illegal won't help the situation. The tragedy is accepting that all we can do is harm reduction, not harm elimination. We can ensure purity; we can develop treatments for physical addiction and promote psychological therapies that work; we can do needle swaps; we can tell people what doses are safe; we can advise people who might have a genetic predisposition to addiction to a given substance; we can even designate specific places or establishment for using and enforce DUI laws. We can enforce regulations governing manufacture and distribution.

What we shouldn't do is draw lines between soft and hard drugs (which are arbitrary from a chemical standpoint); delude ourselves about the properties or dangers of a given drug; or allow self-righteous concern, grief, or fear override the fact that unless you are free to put whatever you want into your own body, you aren't living in a free country. Part of being an adult is allowing other adults to make stupid decisions and bear the consequences. Part of being an adult is accepting that life comes with a fair amount of tragedy and wastes of potential. It also means acknowledging that smoking something, whatever it is, is going to wreck your lungs.

Kurzgesagt - great job. However, it's not accurate to say call all of the effects of the War on Drugs unintentional consequences. One of them, the incarceration of African-Americans, was an explicit goal of Nixon's. His domestic policy adviser and Watergate co-conspirator John Ehrlichman had this to say:

“You want to know what this was really all about?” he asked with the bluntness of a man who, after public disgrace and a stretch in federal prison, had little left to protect. “The Nixon campaign in 1968, and the Nixon White House after that, had two enemies: the antiwar left and black people. You understand what I’m saying? We knew we couldn’t make it illegal to be either against the war or black, but by getting the public to associate the hippies with marijuana and blacks with heroin, and then criminalizing both heavily, we could disrupt those communities. We could arrest their leaders, raid their homes, break up their meetings, and vilify them night after night on the evening news. Did we know we were lying about the drugs? Of course we did.”

Such an important aspect of the story deserves to be mentioned, however briefly, if you are going to discuss the War on Drugs.

There’s only two ways to end the war on drugs:

The first way would be very undesirable, and would operate a legal system with almost religious rigour. Create clear and concise hardcore drug legislation with no loopholes, and implement the death penalty as the punishment for all drug related crimes including non-violent drug use. This will basically be a drug addict holocaust with the same goal as the original holocaust: purge society from all undesirables so that those that remain will be pure and clean.

The second would be a harm-reduction-focused anarcho-capitalist approach to drugs. Make all drugs legal, let the free market produce and sell drugs however they please, and simply make any drugs that have been proven to cause drops in cognition illegal to use while operating machinery (like driving) and any drugs that impair your perception of reality (such as hallucinogens) illegal to use in public. This would get rid of all the main problems drugs cause, no mass incarceration, no gangs, no smuggling, no cartels. And it would still protect the sober from the impaired. There’s no way to make a government mandated recovery program in a country like the u.s. so perhaps drug production companies would have to pay a special income tax that could be waved if they donate enough of their profits to drug addiction recourse charities, this providing a private incentive to fund drug addiction rehab rather than a government funded one that a) won’t work in the u.s. and b) due to the culture of the u.s. people will refuse the help anyways

Around 4:25 the facts on that are a little skewed. Per your source, stated "Whites were about 45 percent more likely than blacks to sell drugs in 1980....that 6.6 percent of white adolescents and young adults (aged 12 to 25) sold drugs, compared to just 5.0 percent of blacks (a 32 percent difference)." Although this fact is true, what is not being said is that 6.6 percent of 73% of the population is actually a smaller amount per capita then 5.0 of 16% of the population. To make this easier, lets assume that we have a population of 100. So 6.6 divided by 73 gives you .09 while 5.0 of 16 gives you .31. So adjusted to 100, 9 out of 100 whites sold drugs while 31 out of 100 blacks sold drugs, actually making black children 4 times more likely to be selling drugs. Just saying.

The war on drugs was never really meant to stop drug use to begin with. One of Nixon’s top advisors, John Ehrlichman, said the following ~24 years ago:

“The Nixon campaign in 1968, and the Nixon White House after that, had two enemies: the antiwar left and black people. You understand what I'm saying? We knew we couldn't make it illegal to be either against the war or black, but by getting the public to associate the hippies with marijuana and blacks with heroin. And then criminalizing both heavily, we could disrupt those communities. We could arrest their leaders, raid their homes, break up their meetings, and vilify them night after night on the evening news. Did we know we were lying about the drugs? Of course we did.”

And that is why we have the war on drugs, straight from the horse’s mouth. Untold millions of people have and continue to suffer because of the self-absorbed, political opportunist, bigoted pieces of shit that were Nixon and his administration. They capitalized on racism, the mass ignorance of roughly half of American society, the perverted, uber-hawkish bloodlust for war that is so prevalent in our nation and faux-patriotism/nationalism all for political gain. So much for a man who is “not a crook.” And generations of idiots have kept this game up for decades, because now the ‘war on drugs’ is too entrenched and enriches too many corrupt, bigoted individuals at the expense of millions of people.

The problem is there are elements of "soft care" that don't seem to be needed by other countries like Singapore. The best treatment is a combination of the two approaches. We need to keep dangerous drugs out. We also need to reduce demand for drugs using rehabilitation programs. But we also need to improve living conditions. Neither one solution is a satisfactory answer. Look at Singapore's ridiculously harsh punishment for drug trafficking: death. Why in hell does it work for them? Look at the traffic of Ecstasy. The Netherlands do not have a very harsh and punitive war on drugs. Still, why is death from that drug unusually high? Like I said, the best solution is a tailor-made mix-and-match one. The best solution also differs country to country. DO NOT FORGET THE LIVING CONDITIONS. A seemingly bad life gives a great incentive to do drugs. If life is not good, then end it. Makes sense.

The US claims to be the upholder for equality and universal human rights internationally, but under the hood it is disrespecting them all the time. It discriminates against so many using a barrage of social barriers, yet frames them such that those problems can be blamed on the sufferers themselves.

In the mindset of the US justice system, the default solution to any individual with any offense, is fines and jail. Capital punishment is less common now but underneath all of those 'solutions', they share the same root: remove the problematic individuals from the society, whether by physically removing (death), effectively removing (incarceration), or economically muting (fines). This could not have been any less than a blatant disregard of the 'equality' that the nation so proudly upholds, and yet is so casually masked behind the logic 'they got what they deserved and they have themselves to blame'.

Indeed, the isolation solution has been universally adopted in history, is still in use in most countries around the world, and the US is by far not the worst. I am only picking on the US because a 21st century superpower with the most influence around the world in every countable way should not sit content with a prehistoric methodology that generates new problems every day.

Like how opening up social opportunities to previously discriminated groups (e.g. women, colored people during WWI and WWII) led to concrete benefits such as increased productivity, attempting to normalize rather than isolate this currently incriminated population by means of education and harm reduction is the most effective and efficient way forward. The society as a whole needs to stop seeing these people as intrinsic demons in need of segregation, instead as sufferers of unfortunate situations in need of help. And the government needs to take the initiative to rework the prison system: less punishment, more education, consoling, and care. Northern European countries have already tried the waters and benefits so far seem well worth it. Now it's the US' turn to implement and further spread the idea. Hopefully a better world will arise out of these efforts.

"By the end of the Chinese Civil War, there were literally millions of opium addicts in the country. The new government immediately set about coping with the monumental problem. Peasants were persuaded to plough in their opium crops and sow wheat or rice instead. Neighbourhoods were mobilised in a massive educational programme. The street committees which governed the neighbourhoods held study groups in which the evils of opium and heroin were discussed. Families of known addicts were educated not to blame their addict members, but to encourage them to seek help. Addicts themselves were impressed by the fact that they were not blamed for their addiction, since they were considered victims of foreign governments and other enemies of the people. After their cure, they were given training and then placed in paying jobs. Many of them were hired by the government to work with other addicts.

At the same time, pressure was placed on the dealers. Those who surrendered were accepted by the community, re-educated, trained for meaningful work and given jobs. I can comment directly on harm reduction due to where I live. It is a massive failure. In Vancouver they established safe injection sites, free needle/crack pipes,  methadone programs, the government bought all the seedy hotels and cleaned them up. There are dozens of agencies "helping" addicts . It was and still is held up as a model for harm reduction. The results - in 2016 there was a dramatic increase in ODs - 1400 people died in a city of 2 million including 17 in one day. 2017 is on a course to smash through the 2016 record. Cheap and powerful fentanyl is the problem.  So in their wisdom they decided to give addicts free morphine. They go every day to the drug store to get their morphine which they then sell on the street and use the money to buy more fentanyl. Yes the person is supposed to take the morphine pills right in the pharmacy but they are junkies and will do whatever to smuggle it out. The pharmacies also get paid a per diem so they turn a blind eye on the junkies leaving with the pills. HIV is down but who cares because that is treatable and most addicts will die of overdose long before AIDS. The downtown east side (DEST) is a disaster zone. Ambulances and paramedics are running through the streets 24x7, drug dealers on every corner. You can and I am not exaggerating buy down (fentanyl or heroin) or cocaine within 60 seconds in the DEST 24x365. If this is what success looks like I would hate to see what failure looks like. I was in the Netherlands a short time ago where they were thinking of putting a safe injection site in a neighborhood in Haarlem. The Vancouver "model" was held up as one that was highly successful. I showed the hotel owners public available stats and picture of what the model resulted in. I know the people that brought it in meant well but now they distort and lie about what is happening. They cannot however hide the death rate and the government hotels/SROs are unbelievable - junkies shooting up in the hallways and stairwells and rooms and all of this right under the noses in clear sight of the staff that work there. I agree the war on drugs is a massive failure but so is harm reduction which has turned into ennoblement.

I live in Portugal. In the 80s and 90s we had a major drug problem, especially heroin. Drug-related crime was ridiculously high and there was a sharp increase in HIV. Our government switched from a hardline policy to rehabilitation, with surprisingly good results. I grew up during those times and I saw how harmful heroin can be to a society, and the difference today is unbelievable. Drug addicts have several places where they receive new needles, get HIV screening and most important of all, information. The staff are trained to steer them towards rehabilitation. We decriminalized drug possession up to a certain amount, which stopped draining government money and resources on pointless arrests of drug addicts and spent the money instead on rehabilitation programs. Today, drug-related crime decreased and we seldom see drug addicts on the streets (in contrast to the ubiquitous used syringes everywhere).  I'm sad to see the US government hasn't learned yet from the ever-increasing amount of successful examples of that change in strategy. Drug addicts are victims, not criminals. A dumb, non-violent, self-harming mistake shouldn't ruin your life, and if they aren't marginalized and pushed towards an increasingly criminal lifestyle and reintegrated into society instead, they can quickly become productive members of society again.

Simple way to stop drug cartels:

1. Body cams on ALL Mexican police and military
2. Legalize Marijuana
3. Legalize the right to bare arms
4. Use military police to mop up
5. Target cartel leadership

The body cams have been used in areas of high corruption. In Texas, police corruption was cut by 80% and over a dozen corrupt employees were fired from the use of body cameras.
Legalizing marijuana will not end cartel funding, but it will put a HUGE dent in their pocket, shorting them by hundreds of millions annually.
Arming civilians will act as a deterrent to home intrusions, government corruption, and can greatly reduce civilian casualties and even increase casualties on cartel affiliates from citizen militias.
Military police can conduct checkpoints, and patrol the hottest regions in Mexico with military firepower to mop up pockets of disorganized weakened cartels.
Finally, targeting cartel bosses can disorganize these highly organized drug lords. Sending police snipers to neutralize a cartel groups main boss and his right hand man will leave those groups with less experienced cartels to struggle running the drug operation which will be followed by many mistakes and failed drug missions making it easier for Mexican government officials to handle.

What is rarely discussed about the war on drugs is how the main purpose of it was to provide cover for mass disenfrachisement of non-whites in America, when drug possession (not manufacture and distribution) was made a felony which was then paired with felony disenfranchisement, which strips voting rights. Compound that the American legal system is more likely to judge possession crimes a misdemeanor or other non-felony for white and often more affluent citizens than for non-whites, and that a loophole in the 13th amendment allows for prison labor, you have a system that is effectively a slavery system in all but name and the whips are made of red tape rather than woven leather. Furthermore, since there is a cultural stigma against those with felony records and no desire to give the support needed to lift them out of poverty, entire communities are held down for generations to the detriment of the local and national economy. This doesn't have to be, it is a choice made to cement the power of a select few who would rather have an ever larger share of a shrinking pie and increased instability, rather than invest a tiny fraction of that share into making a bigger pie, resulting in a larger pie and ultimately a larger share overall.

I am a libertarian, that means i think any and all drug regulations should not exist for a large number of reasons that all stem ultimately from a very hard-line philosophical ideology in libertarianism. Libertarians could not be more against the drug war. However, libertarians are also very strongly and vehemently opposed to any kind of publicly-funded rehabilitation program for addicts for reasons stemming from the same ideological principles. Libertarians would have countries' governments address the problem of drugs by very stringently and dogmatically refusing to be involved in any way with anything or anyone related to drugs that is not also involved in an actual crime. Even though it does appear true that vast community benefits can arise from providing state care to addicts, we believe that it is categorically wrong to do so for ideological reasons and while we would of course encourage everyone to donate to non-profit charities that could be involved in such endeavors, we could not be more opposed to a government operation to do the same. (some libertarians may disagree and that is valid, it is because moderate libertarians believe that at present all nations are so far removed from the ideal of radical libertarianism that it is the most useful to try to focus on just small changes to the most important issues, to make the most difference that can be made in a world where libertarianism is really very unpopular and typically unknown. I and other radical libertarians believe that the ultimate goal should be this very far-removed ideal, though the focus can be made on changes that can actually take place and have a positive effect on the very un-libertarian modern world)

One of the worst sides to the Drug War is that it shames and presents helpless drug addicts as criminals and scum. Not only is this counterinuitive to actually helping these people, but this also deeply alienates them as well (which may of course lead to other problems, such as increased suicide rates, homelessness and crime). Imagine being addicted to heroin and being turned away by your own family and friends—having no sort of emotional support which is often the very thing you'd desperately need in this situation. Spending every penny on another fix until you're either broke, dead, or actively robbing others. Now imagine this on a grand scale of thousands and millions, such as we have today. The Drug War is a miserable failure, not only for the reason it was supposedly created for (of preventing societal harm), but for singlehandedly escalating this problem. This needs to end.

Stricter border control would be the best go to and considering that the Mexican government is in bed with the cartels it might be the only option. We do not have the budget to freely open centers for controlled usage, facilities to house users, doctors to overlook treatment, and social workers for rehabilitation and reintegration. Switzerland is not a good example because they do not share the same issues we do in terms of militarized cartels and a corrupt border country. Even then they still experience illicit drug use so proof there that it's not a perfect solution.

It is true that the war on drugs has failed to solve the problem from the supply side of the equation, but there is still a responsibility to enforce drug laws and prosecute criminals. It may be inefficient, but society cannot just give up and let criminals have their way. The best solution is to attack the problem from both sides. Use a harm reduction strategy in conjunction with a crime reduction strategy. The merits of harm reduction would then be obtained and justice can still be served.

While the Switzerland idea seems very good (and it it !) it is hardly applicable to the USA. It worked because Switzerland is a small country, and it was easy to implant heroin maintenance centers. In the US, it's obviously more complicated. You cannot try this only on a few states for obvious reason, it would create a huge imbalance and harm surrounding states who do not provide free drugs; and doing this on a country scale is almost impossible : you can't "try an experiment" on such a scale like they did in Switzerland, it will be extremely hard to make everyone agree to spend huge amounts of money to build centers all around the US, etc.
I'm sure there is a better way than the war on drugs though. But any idea would be way harder to implement in the huge country that is the USA than in place smaller than 1/8 of Texas.

A great video. One suggestion. You point out that the DEA gets $30billion but that is only part of the story. I think you needed to outline the dollars spent on the drug war in total. If you lock up a father, you take away a source of income which can put a mother and children on welfare. Also, it would help to give the estimated dollars needed to implement a Stop The Harm program in the US.

IMO if you want to change minds, you need to show how this problem hits the pocketbook. I was always of the mindset that supported the War On Drugs until I learned a lot more about the costs and effectiveness. It became obvious to me that any continuance of such a program was insanity. Even though I'm pretty politically conservative, I think it's long past time to try something new. The Stop the Harm campaign may, at the very least, be worth trying.

This video was well argued but not well balanced. It was designed to convince the viewer of Kurzgesagt's political position, rather than to analyse the problem. That's okay, if rather out of place for a pop-science channel, given science's objective nature. For an example of an important issue omitted from the video due to its falling on the other side of the debate, consider the cost of providing the recommended health service. Developed countries generally spend very large portions of their budget on healthcare, and healthcare budgets generally increase at a rate outstripping inflation for a variety of factors. The long term economic implications of Kurzgesagt's proposed policy are complicated, and rather off-putting. That isn't to say Kurzgesagt's position is wrong. I just think it is important to intake this piece of media whilst understanding its bias.

On a separate point, it is worth noting that anyone who intentionally uses illegal drugs at the moment is likely contributing to crime and harm (unless you know the exact way in which your drugs were produced, and are sure no one was harmed in their production). The point of this is that to use illegal drugs now is probably wrong, because the use of the drugs supports the harmful means by which they were produced and transported. Hopefully this serves to encourage people to not use drugs at the moment, especially imported drugs, because of the negative effect they have on the world. Acknowledging this does not prevent one from campaigning for legalisation or other laws, of course.

I find it ironic that people so harshly look down on and judge those on welfare, calling them leaches on society, when most of those people where either born disabled, or are by a terrible accident. What Kurzgesagt is talking about, is giving addicts free drugs payed for by the government. People who are on drugs are people who chose to try them, and got addicted. At this point in America, people have been taught well enough about drugs, their side effects, and how the government deals with them, to know the consequences of their actions, and be choosing to except them. Even if they only meant to try a drug, they knew there was a chance they'd get addicted, and took that risk. Everything that follows is on them.
Why should welfare be cut when the country is in economic crisis, but people who are addicts get free drugs? Someone can be born unable to work for themselves, be hit by a car, or something like that, but no one is born holding a heroine needle, and no one walking on the side of the street suddenly gets hit by one, and has it happen to them again and again until they become dependent on it.
Think of the purge, it's a dystopian society where one night a year people are allowed to commit any crime they want, because the government gave up on fighting it. How's that different from giving addicts free drugs? A whole group of criminals (I.E. dealers and customers) Is going to be legalized in this hypothetical scenario, because they put up so much of a fuss killing and stealing, that the U.S government just gives in, and actually enables them by GIVING them drugs and housing. What other groups of criminals are going to be humored because they're a danger to themselves and others? What ever happened to "America doesn't negotiate wit terrorists"?
If you are an average human being, you are capable of following the law, and working in society. You don't have the right to choose to get addicted to something, become a danger to yourself and others because of it, and then use that as a way of negotiating what laws you will and won't follow, and where, when and how you'll be a productive member of society again. No one deserves that kind of special treatment, not even the president should be allowed to act like that, so why should any random citizen.
Do you think if we were to start doing this, everybody else in society would continue to do their jobs and pay their rent, and stay off drugs? No. There would be no legal consequence to doing drugs, and there would be benefits. And despite the law, drugs will still continue to have horrible physical consequences. We can't have a society of people with fried brain cells and weak, breaking bodies by their own self infliction, telling the police the government or whoever that they will and will not be a drain on society, or a hazard to others whenever they do and don't feel like it. And the worst part, this wouldn't be like welfare where you have to be born disabled, or be disabled by an accident or something. Anyone would be able to find drugs, get addicted, and then get more for free. There are people who take advantage of welfare, but most people wouldn't face the terrible pain of breaking their legs to permanently cripple themselves, or give themselves a life threatening heart condition that makes it dangerous for them run or physically exert themselves. What would someone have to do to get on the free drugs and housing program? Get high and keep doing it for free. Why should we add a whole new branch of what's basically welfare, for people facing the consequences of their CHOICES? It's not that much better than sending them to prison, except they still get to do drugs and have free range of the streets. It's basically wasting tax dollars to not solve the problem.
Yes, there are problems with the war on drugs, and no it isn't very effective, but one percent is still saving millions of people, as appose to enabling them. Things do need to change and be made more efficient, but not by legalizing everything, and giving away drugs for free on tax dollars. That's the exact opposite of helping, for the same if not higher price in taxes.

GDP per Capita of USA: $53,041.98
GDP per Capita of Switzerland: $84,815.41

Taking this into account the swiss have $32k extra to spend over the average American. I'm not saying that the USA isn't spending their resources wisely, but it is definitely worth noting that Switzerland is a much richer country than the US. Thus it has the resources to spend on lots of social health/ general social care.

Now, if they could spend the $30 billion every year on a USA wide social drug care system, then you'd have a good argument. The US is 9.857 million m^2 so that is roughly $3000 per square meter. This video makes this topic look so easy. Whoever believes this is mighty ignorant. Switzerland also used punishment as a tool to fight drugs and their prisions were filled with drug dealers. The used a double strategy, to fight demand and supply at the same time. That being said, Switzerland is a country way smaller and easier to control and handle than the USA. Their borders were secured, and it was easy to build up the needed infrastructure as the drug problem only peaked in a few larger cities. This is not comparable  to the US - I am not saying the US is fighting drugs correctly and a lot of problems mentioned are very serious, but it is not like the US did not think about this strategy before.

As an American, I thank you for this video. The war on drugs here in the US is a bunch of bullshit. Hell, I was once addicted to a drug many years ago, and as someone with no money.. when I finally realized how bad my life had gotten and wanted to stop, I tried to get help. After calling everywhere in the state, my options were basically go to rehab for 600-1000+ dollars.. more than I had.. or get a free crappy counselor meeting (where I was told I'd have to wait 5-6 months just to get into a little 20-30 minute talk/session with them). Oh, and there was one other option, which was a methadone clinic. Not only did I have to pay for it.. it was a 45 minute drive from where I lived. And with these clinics, you have to come there once a day just to get your doses for that one day. I didn't even own a car. So, I was pretty much forced to do a really dangerous cold turkey, which was potentially deadly because of how serious it was. Though, thankfully, I'm alive, obviously.

And now, because I had one drug addiction once in my life many years ago, and never had any other drug/alcohol abuse history, nor any criminal record whatsoever.. I've been treated like shit by doctors and those in the medical field ever since then. It's just sad, really.

And the whole so called "war on drugs" hasn't helped anyone.. it really is just a joke. As much as I do like living in the US, there's some really dumb issues that need fixed.. and need to stop now, instead of being dragged on and ignored. This is one of those issues. I just hope that, whoever ends up winning the election, ends up stopping this idiotic parade once and for all.

We're not able to provide them with clean drugs ourselves because the program doesn't have the authority to break the law in that way and that's unlikely to change. The program is already disliked by many people in common society and government for how ineffective it has been and the perceived apathy of the users who simply never go to it, whether that is actually the case or not.
The safe injection sites only continue to operate because of independent donations and volunteers at this point. Many of those who work there are still frustrated by their lack of authority to even suggest drug treatment for people because of a 'no judgment' policy.
There are a lot of organizational potholes that still need to be overcome for a system like Switzerland's to even get off the ground in countries without an large socially minded leaning.

The types of people that oppose the legalization of cannabis for adults:

1. The Bible-thumper: Those who have never read Genesis 1:11, 1:29, 9:3, and Ecclesiasticus 38:4 or just ignore them.

2. The Authoritarian: Those that think that people have the right to tell another peaceable person what they can or cannot put on or in their own body under threat of physical and monetary punishment.

3. The Sheep: Those who just do as they are told without question and think the government knows what's best for them. Remember, slavery was legal. The Holocaust was legal. Segregation was legal. Never use the state as a metric of ethics.

4. The Over Protective Parent: Those who don't want it in the hands of children, yet they probably have alcohol and prescription drugs in the fridge or cupboard, not realizing that those can kill their children and cannabis cannot.

5. The Ignorant: Those who think that it can kill you even though it has an ED50:LD50 of between 1:20,000-1:40,000; and those who think it has no medicinal value even though we have things like Marinol and U.S. Patent #6630507. Those that think smoking cannabis is the only way to ingest it and those that think it kills brain cells. http://www.drugpolicy.org/blog/does-marijuana-kill-brain-cells

6. The Idiot: Those who aren't intelligent enough to realize that something that can't kill you (cannabis) is unequivocally less dangerous than something that can kill you (alcohol, caffeine, cocaine, crack, heroin, meth, nicotine, prescription drugs). It is a safer alternative to lethal, recreational chemicals.

7. The A**hole: Those who don't want to admit that they have been wrong all these years and/or have punished someone for it.

8. The Pig: Those who enjoy depriving humans of their life, liberty, happiness, loved ones and possessions over non-violent, victim-less acts such as possessing an all-natural and 100% non-lethal plant. Also, anyone who benefits from asset forfeiture. Cops, judges, prosecutors.

9. The Greedy: Those who stand to lose money if it was legalized nationally. Cops, judges, prosecutors, cartels, the private prison system, oil companies, Big Pharma, lumber industries, alcohol companies, tobacco companies, etc.

10. The Hypocrites: Those who think it makes you dumb, yet they will never be as intelligent as Carl Sagan; those who think it makes you lazy, yet will never be as physically adept as Micheal Phelps; and those who think it makes people worthless, yet will never be as talented as their favorite musician. Also, people who drink alcohol and say that drugs are bad, not realizing that alcohol is a drug.

11. The Nosy: Those who want it to stay illegal because they don't like the smell of it. Even though by that logic we should outlaw cooking meat because vegans don't like the smell of burning flesh. They probably think we should outlaw farts and water treatment plants, too.

12. The Straight edge: The arrogant people who think that because they don't want or like something, no one else should be allowed.

13. The Gateway theorists: Those that think it is a gateway drug. If that's true, Willie Nelson has some explaining to do. Also, curiosity is the only gateway drug.

14. The "it causes crime" people: Cannabis doesn't cause crime, prohibition does. Example: Alcohol prohibition and Al Capone.http://www.drugpolicy.org/resource/marijuana-legalization-colorado-one-year-status-report

15. The "what message does it send to the kids?" people: It sends them the message to not ingest lethal recreational chemicals. It sends the message that intelligent people know that cannabis is far less dangerous than any man-made chemical.
BONUS: How to talk to your kids about drugs; 1. Don't do drugs. 2. Don't do drugs. 3. If you are going to use drugs, choose the only one that can't kill you from overdose.

Cannabis doesn't kill people, people kill people; which, ironically, makes it unequivocally less dangerous than the evil, soulless, sub-human sloppy pools of maggot ridden dog excrement who support and enforce it's prohibition; and those that support the enforcers that have failed miserably at their endeavor to eradicate it from our country.

Note: If you don't oppose the legalization of cannabis, none of these apply to you. Also, I didn't write this for your arrogant ass. I copied and pasted it to a notepad after I wrote it a long time ago.

We are going to need some time to work out the minutia of harm reduction. A good example is the issue of pregnant mothers on maintenance therapy. However, it is often the case that once their children are born, even though they followed the advice of their addiction specialist and obgyn, the state will open a CPS case and often take their children.

Probably, reducing the demand is the only way out (at least whilst we don't have a super AI controlling everything in the world and fixing every problem for us, and maybe without us), but part of the demand is caused by irresponsible attitudes, like trying hard drugs just for fun, or because it's "cool" in your group of friends. In Spain there's a social reward for irresponsible but "funny" attitudes, and no matter how much effort you put into making people more sensible, it's like those wanting to be irresponsible are going to be it no matter what.

Anyway, in market terms, being the State a monopoly drug cartels can't fight is much better strategy than directly attacking a cancer in methastasis phase like production lines in poor countries. Unless you are prepared to spend trillions in helping those countries become first world countries with much better security forces (with the collateral effect of giving those countries the opportunity to use their own resources without the need to sell them to the first world at laughable prices)

“Psychedelics are illegal not because a loving government is concerned that you may jump out of a third story window. Psychedelics are illegal because they dissolve opinion structures and culturally laid down models of behaviour and information processing. They open you up to the possibility that everything you know is wrong.”
“Part of what psychedelics do is they decondition you from cultural values. This is what makes it such a political hot potato. Since all culture is a kind of con game, the most dangerous candy you can hand out is one which causes people to start questioning the rules of the game.” (Terence McKenna)

"The state sends us to prison for essentially exploring our own consciousness.
This is a grotesque abuse of human rights. It's a fundamental wrong.
If I as an adult am not sovereign over my own consciousness, then I'm absolutely not sovereign over anything. I can't claim any kind of freedom at all.
We have been persuaded to hand over the keys of our consciousness to the state.
The most precious, the most intimate, the most sapien part of ourselves - the state now has the keys. And furthermore, they've persuaded us that that's in our interest." (Graham Hancock)

“We are infantilized, we're told: “You can wonder around within the sanctioned playpen of ordinary consciousness, and we have some intoxicants over here if you want to mess yourself up: we've got some scotch here, some tobacco, and red meat, and some sugar, and a little TV, and so forth and so on...” but, these boundary-dissolving-hallucinogens that give you a sense of unity with your fellow men and nature are somehow forbidden.” (Terence Mckenna)
